name: Avalon

longDescription:
County Mayo, Ireland Croagh Patrick (Irish: Cruach Phadraig, "Patrick's Stack") is Ireland's holiest mountain, a 764-meter
                (2,507-foot) peak overlooking Clew Bay in County Mayo. For over 5,000 years, this conical quartzite
                mountain has been a place of pilgrimage - first for pre-Christian Celtic peoples who honored the
                harvest god Crom Dubh, and then for Christians following in the footsteps of St. Patrick. According
                to tradition, in 441 CE, Patrick fasted on the summit for forty days and forty nights, emulating
                Moses and Christ, and it was here that he banished all snakes from Ireland. Today, over 100,000
                pilgrims climb "the Reek" annually, many barefoot, making it one of the most important Christian
                pilgrimage sites in Europe.

name: Croagh Patrick

longDescription:
Paimpont Forest, Brittany, France The Forest of Broceliande is the legendary enchanted woodland of Arthurian romance, where Merlin
                was imprisoned by the Lady of the Lake, where the fairy Viviane was born, and where knights of
                the Round Table sought adventure among its magical groves. Today identified with the Forest of
                Paimpont in central Brittany, this ancient woodland has been associated with the Arthurian
                legends since at least the 12th century, when poets like Chretien de Troyes and the anonymous
                authors of the Vulgate Cycle set their magical tales within its bounds. The forest remains a
                place of pilgrimage for those seeking the living memory of Camelot and the old Celtic magic
                that predates the medieval romances.

name: Forest of Broceliande

longDescription:
Somerset, England Glastonbury Tor rises dramatically from the Somerset Levels, a striking conical hill topped by
                the ruined tower of St. Michael's Church. At 518 feet (158 meters), this ancient landmark has
                drawn pilgrims, mystics, and seekers for millennia. The Tor is steeped in layers of legend: it
                is identified with the mystical Isle of Avalon, burial place of King Arthur; associated with
                early Christian traditions surrounding Joseph of Arimathea and the Holy Grail; and connected to
                pre-Christian Celtic beliefs about the Otherworld and fairy realms. This remarkable convergence
                of pagan, Arthurian, and Christian sacred geography makes Glastonbury one of Britain's most
                spiritually significant sites.

                the ruined tower of St. Michael's Church. At 518 feet (158 meters), thi
name: Glastonbury Tor
